    • Field Detail

      • arguments

        private java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object> arguments
        Stores the arguments of the method.

        Arguments can store ints, doubles, Strings, classes, and other TFMethods

      • argumentTypes

        private java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Class> argumentTypes
        Stores the classes of the arguments.

        Each argument type corresponds with an argument by index

      • originalArguments

        private java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Object> originalArguments
        Stores the original arguments of this TFMethod.

        These are useful because arguments that are methods are replaced with their output in the arguments.

        This will allow the methods to be used again.

      • method

        private java.lang.reflect.Method method
        Stores the method of the TFMethod to be invoked.

      • field

        private java.lang.Object field
        Stores the Object that the method will be invoked on.

        Fields can be of the field class or TFMethods that return a value that is then used as the field.

      • requirements

        private java.util.ArrayList<Requirement> requirements
        Stores the requirements of the method (Only used in premethods and postmethods of locations and enemies).

        These are used to determine if the conditions are right for the method to be invoked.

      • invokeMethod

        public java.lang.Object invokeMethod()
        returns the output of the method.

        First, the game invokes all arguments that are methods and replaces the argument that the method occupied with its output. Next, the game determines if the field is a Field or a FieldMethod. If it is a FieldMethod, then it invokes the method and sets the fieldvalue to the output of the field method (the fieldvalue is a local variable, that is used in invoking the method). If it is a regular Field, then set fieldvalue to the value that the field stores.

        Returns:
        The output of the method.

      • putInputInArguments

        public boolean putInputInArguments(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> inputArgs)
        The method replaces any placeholders ("%ph%[indexOfInput]") with inputArgs and replaces any placeholders in any arguments that are TFMethods.

        This is only called if it is a child of a ChoiceMethod or a distant child of one.

        If everything goes well, the method returns the true. The method returns false if an argument is messed up fill the arguments array to the correct size (The size of the argumentTypes).

        If an argument (not the inputArgs) is null, the game just places null into the new methodArgs array.

        If an argument is just a regular argument, the game just places the argument into the new methodArgs array.

        If an argument is a TFMethod, thez the game invokes putInputInArguments() on it (Replaces placeholders with the inputArgs). If false is returned from this, then return false, because that means there is a problem. If an argument is a placeholder ("%ph%"), then the game gets the number to the right of "%ph%" and calls inputArgs.get(index) and casts the output to the argumentType. When done, arguments is set to methodArgs.

        If the field is a FieldMethod, then invoke putInputInArguments on it (Which just does the exact same thing as explained here). If that returns -1, then return -1, because that means there is a problem (Likely from not enough input arguments).

        Parameters:
        inputArgs - The arraylist of the player's input arguments.
        Returns:
        whether or not successful.

      • resetArguments

        public void resetArguments()
        resetArguments sets the arguments to the originalArguments. The method loops through each argument and invokes resetArguments() on each TFMethod. It invokes resetArguments() on the field if it is a FieldMethod.
